questionList.qu: Zoophobas morio is an insect. Its larvae feed on bat feces in caves in Guatemala. What type of organism is a Zoophobas morio larva?
questionList.solution: A Zoophobas morio larva is a detritivore, which means it feeds on dead organic matter, such as bat feces. It is not an autotroph, which produces its own food through photosynthesis, nor a consumer, which feeds on living organisms. It is also not a saprotroph, which feeds on decaying organic matter.

questionList.qu: Which term best defines a group of populations living and interacting with each other in an area?
questionList.solution: Community. In ecology, a community refers to all the living organisms (i.e. populations) of different species that interact with each other in a particular area or habitat.

questionList.qu: Which of the following trophic groups include fungi?
questionList.solution: Fungi are decomposers that obtain nutrients by breaking down dead organic matter, such as leaves, wood, and other plant material. They play an important role in nutrient cycling by releasing nutrients back into the soil, which can then be taken up by plants or other organisms.

questionList.qu: What is the mode of nutrition of midge larva?
questionList.solution: Midge larvae are aquatic insects that feed on a variety of organic matter, including algae, bacteria, and small invertebrates. They are considered to be primary consumers in aquatic food webs, and are an important food source for many larger predators. While they may occasionally feed on detritus, they are primarily predators and thus obtain their nutrients by consuming other organisms.

questionList.qu: Which represents a correct food chain from this web?
questionList.a3: diatom → midge larva → caddisfly larva → stickleback
questionList.a4: filamentous algae → mayfly nymph → leech → stickleback
questionList.solution: Diatoms are unicellular algae that form the base of many aquatic food webs. Midge larvae are primary consumers that feed on the diatoms, and caddisfly larvae are secondary consumers that feed on the midge larvae. Sticklebacks are tertiary consumers that feed on the caddisfly larvae.

questionList.qu: What is the classification of an organism that is able to make organic compounds from inorganic nutrients?
questionList.solution: Autotrophs are organisms that are able to synthesize their own organic compounds from simple inorganic substances such as carbon dioxide and water, using energy from the sun or other sources. This ability to produce their own food makes autotrophs the basis of most food chains and ecosystems. Examples of autotrophs include green plants, algae, and some bacteria.

questionList.qu: Euglena is a unicellular organism that feeds on bacteria and uses CO2 as a carbon source. Which describes the nutrition of this organism?
questionList.solution: is both autotrophic and heterotrophic. Euglena is a unicellular organism that can produce its own food using photosynthesis (autotrophic), but can also feed on bacteria when light is not available (heterotrophic). During photosynthesis, Euglena uses carbon dioxide (CO2) as a carbon source and produces oxygen (O2) as a byproduct. When light is not available, Euglena can switch to heterotrophic mode and obtain its nutrients by feeding on other organisms, such as bacteria. This unique ability to switch between different modes of nutrition allows Euglena to survive in a wide range of environments.

questionList.solution: The average conversion efficiency from primary to secondary consumers in most ecosystems is about 10%. Therefore, the correct option is B.

questionList.qu: Which group of organisms in the carbon cycle converts carbon into a form that is available to primary consumers?
questionList.solution: Producers, such as plants, algae, and some bacteria, convert inorganic carbon (usually in the form of carbon dioxide) into organic compounds through photosynthesis. These organic compounds are then consumed by primary consumers, such as herbivores, which pass the carbon up the food chain.
